reasoning:
1. Circle of Competence: Amazon’s mix of global e-commerce logistics and high-tech cloud computing sits outside my circle. I know retail goods and simple distribution, but AWS is complex – I can’t predict long-term cloud economics.
2. Competitive Moat: Yes, Amazon has scale and brand power, and AWS has a lead in cloud. But inconsistent ROE (only 1.8% last year, zero periods above 15% in the last decade) and razor-thin retail margins mean the moat may not be as deep or durable as Coca-Cola’s.
3. Management & Capital Allocation: I admire Bezos’s vision, but I prefer owners who return cash via dividends or buybacks. Amazon’s dilution through new stock issuance and minimal returns to shareholders don’t fit my playbook.
4. Financial Health & Consistency: A debt-to-equity of 1.8 and a 66% drop in earnings over the last ten periods are red flags. Operating margins may look strong today, but uneven earnings growth argues against financial fortress credentials.
5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: Your three-stage DCF pegs fair value around $1,033, yet the stock trades multiples above that, leaving no margin of safety (–99%). I won’t pay up for uncertainty.
6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: E-commerce is competitive, and regulatory or technological shifts in cloud could erode AWS’s advantage. Without clear visibility, it’s hard to own this "forever." 
7. Comparison to My Portfolio: I’d rather deploy capital in entrenched consumer brands or insurance franchises with predictable cash flow. When I compare Amazon to Coca-Cola or See’s Candies, the risk-reward doesn’t pencil out.
In my view, the best opportunities are simple businesses with lasting moats, honest management, and a built-in margin of safety. Amazon doesn’t check those boxes at today’s price.

fundamental_analysis.details: Weak ROE of 1.8%; High debt to equity ratio of 1.8; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of -66.1% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 0/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 24.8%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Good book value per share growth pattern

management_analysis.details: Recent common stock issuance (potential dilution); No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
